subject: RE: [junit] Testing Complete Applications and Applets
msgSnippet: Hello Vincent, It is me, thanks for coming back. I am actually using log4j, but I mentioned system.out.writeln as a simplification. The real problem I had
messageBody:
Hello Vincent,

It is me, thanks for coming back. I am actually using log4j, but I mentioned
system.out.writeln as a simplification.

The real problem I had really is how to invoke the entire application/applet
inside a test case. It is easy to write a testcase to invoke a particular
method in a particular class. However I cannot simply call the init() in the
JApplet implementation - I need to simulate the applet life-cycle. Of course
I would have to simulate the keystrokes and mouse - I am investigating Jemmy
for this purpose.

The situation is not as complicated with applications, since I should be
able to simply call the main() with the appropriate arguments.

Regards,
Stephen
-----Original Message-----
From: Vincent Massol [mailto:vmassol@...]
Sent: 21 March 2002 12:19
To: stephen.cheng@...
Subject: RE: [junit] Testing Complete Applications and Applets


Stephen,

Are you the Stephen Cheng I met at Icom ?

There are several solutions to your question.

1/ First it is not good to do System.out.println ! You should rather use
a logging toolkit. I would suggest Jakarta Commons Logging as it
transparently let you use log4j, jdk1.4, logkit or simple logging using
system.out, I think. If you do this, then you can provide a mock
implementation of the logger and assert whatever you want.

2/ Simply redirect the out stream to a memory stream and then compare
the memory stream with the expected result.

Hope it helps.
-Vincent
